div.h1: Semantic Blumenbach: Exploration of Text–Object Relationships with Semantic Web Technology in the History of Science

div.div: Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities, Germany

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 30, Issue suppl_1, December 2015, Pages i187–i198, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqv047

div.p: Jörg Wettlaufer, Christopher Johnson, Martin Scholz, Mark Fichtner, Sree Ganesh Thotempudi, Semantic Blumenbach: Exploration of Text–Object Relationships with Semantic Web Technology in the History of Science, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 30, Issue suppl_1, December 2015, Pages i187–i198, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqv047

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: There are many ways to model relationships between texts and objects. Creating statements with RDF triples is one of them. In the project ‘Semantic Blumenbach', we have endeavoured to discover and render visible the innate connections of Johann Friedrich Blumenbach's (1752–1840) writings on natural history with the physical objects studied and collected by him. After a careful evaluation of existing frameworks for describing objects and texts, we decided to test the Scientific Communication Infrastructure (WissKI) for this purpose. During the project, new modules have been developed, and a workflow to connect extracted knowledge from Blumenbach’s texts with metadata of objects has been established. The data modelling, the ingest workflow, and project evaluation in the context of the on-going discussion about Linking TEI and CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model are subjects of this article.

div.p: The digital representation of texts and museum objects is curated by two distinct scholarly communities: the TEI markup language consortium for texts and the CIDOC conceptual reference model (CRM) group for cultural heritage objects (Goerz and Scholz, 2009). For 10 years, we have observed efforts to bring these two communities and their on-going development of standards in contact. Christan-Emil Ore and Øyvind Eide published in 2006 a first proposal for the exchange of information between TEI and CIDOC (Eide and Ore, 2006). Since then, additional work has been published on the topic, and the TEI Ontologies Special Interest Group has been established; but, so far, there is no consensus in the communities on how to overcome the challenges (Holmen et al., 2007; Ore and Eide, 2009; Rahtz, 2010; Jourdanous et al., 2012; Eide, 2013; Will, 2013; Ciula and Eide, 2014).1 Although a range of specialized software applications have been developed to meet the special needs and metadata of both categories, none of them meets the expectations of both groups sufficiently up to now.2 While texts can easily be represented as ‘digital objects’, there is currently no cohesive model to store and represent both texts and objects in one system. The encoding methods of TEI are not fully adapted to the needs of event-centric object description, while other entities like places and persons can be mapped easier to CIDOC (Ore and Eide, 2009, p. 168, Fig. 4). Furthermore, texts often consist of meaningful subdivisions that can go down to the word or character level and are not represented by adequate concepts in CIDOC. Given this situation, the Semantic Blumenbach project aims to explore a new approach that allows for a deep linking between objects and texts and builds on common W3C Semantic Web standards.3

After a careful evaluation of existing tools and frameworks, we have chosen a virtual research environment (VRE) known as ‘Scientific Communication Infrastructure' (WissKI). WissKI was developed and maintained initially by the Germanisches Nationalmuseum Nürnberg and later by an association (Interessengemeinschaft für Semantische Datenverarbeitung e.V.,) with the purpose of supporting it.4 WissKI builds on the Drupal CMS and is a modular framework that was conceived to support scientific documentation of museum collections in the context of projects that deal with cultural heritage objects. It is suited to integrate data from the humanities and natural sciences. The data model is based on the Erlangen CRM (ECRM), an OWL-DL version of CIDOC CRM, which is also managed and supported by the group in charge of WissKI (Oischinger et al., 2008).5 The CIDOC CRM defines the modelling of explicit relationships like the identification of real-world entities by real-world names and the references that connect them to information objects (Doerr and Stead, 2012). This enables the creation of new scientific workflows and content management, based on semantic web standards. WissKI depends on Named Entity (names, places, dates, etc.) Recognition (NER) methods and provides several interfaces to relevant standards like LIDO6 and a SPARQL Endpoint.7 However, the system did not initially support the ingest of larger quantities of existing encoded text. One of the primary goals of the Semantic Blumenbach project has been to enhance and modify the WissKI modules and to allow for mass ingest of TEI formatted text.

The modelling of the text–object relationships with ECRM was the key challenge in this project. As CIDOC CRM is an event-centric reference model for describing objects and collections in museums (Scholz, 2013), the option for modelling text-related information is rather limited.8 However, it was possible to represent the classical word/chapter/book hierarchy within the Linguistic Object Class of ECRM. This allowed the development of the relationships between objects and TEI-encoded information about persons, places, dates, and technical terms in an application ontology labelled ‘semblu'.9 The attributes of specific TEI elements provide the information to hyperlink textual entities to the collection objects. Using a semiformal hybrid of OWL and SKOS, these relationships have been constrained with SKOS:exactMatch, but as will be explained later in the discussion, this should be expanded with SKOS-associative properties in the future for a more meaningful description of the text–object relationship.10

The test material of the project has been kindly contributed by the project Johann Friedrich Blumenbach-online, a long-term project (until 2024) of the Göttingen Academy of Sciences and Humanities, started in January 2010, that aims to digitize and present the writings and collections of the influential Göttingen physician and naturalist Johann Friedrich Blumenbach (1752–1840), one of the founding fathers of physical anthropology, online (Kerzel et al., 2013). Blumenbach was a prolific writer as well as an avid collector of objects, ranging from skulls and bones to rocks and minerals. The digitization and creation of both the collection object repository and the repository of texts authored by Blumenbach have been the focus of ‘Blumenbach-online' in the last years (Kroke, 2010).11 To date, almost half of the textual material (77,000 pages altogether) and roughly a quarter of the collections have been digitized and converted into TEI-encoded texts or entered into a MySQL database. Due to the origin of the material, the TEI-encoding schema was already established before the start of Semantic Blumenbach, and it was logical to reuse the already-established schema and to stay as compatible as possible to the standardizations of the original project.12 Although the schema was available, the actual TEI-P5 encoding for entities was not. This encoding had to be established by Semantic Blumenbach during an initial phase of the project as a precondition for the establishment of text–object relationships.13

Finally, the Semantic Blumenbach project exists in the broader context of research data preservation and is defined by the problem of integration of heterogeneous data resources. Through the exploration of Semantic Web technologies and the establishment of a prototypical installation of a VRE, we tested the robustness and performance of an ontologically sourced data model and the related Standards like RDF(S), SPARQL, and OWL.

The whole project has been conducted in several consecutive steps, each building on the other. Data modelling and mapping was not the first step, because the project used the predefined entities by Blumenbach-online, which first had to be identified in the texts. This first step was crucial for the success of the project; but, it also turned out to be a real challenge, because NER on historical texts with a special vocabulary from the natural history domain cannot rely on already existing dictionaries. Many names for animals were invented by Blumenbach and equally many are not in use any longer or can be labelled obsolete today. Therefore, special tools were built to annotate the TEI, and some manual correction had to be taken into consideration.
div.h3: 2.1 NER in historical German TEI-encoded texts
div.p: For the project, a subsample of twelve TEI-tite-encoded texts from the approximate 1,000 texts published by Blumenbach were chosen. The ‘Handbuch der Naturgeschichte', published in twelve German editions between 1779 and 1830, has been one of the most successful books written by Blumenbach. It has also been translated into several other languages; but, given the limited capacity of the project for this task, only the German editions have been taken into consideration. Departing from the 6th edition, published in 1799, a list of persons, places, and special terms was established. A preliminary NER by SynCoPe,14 developed by the Deutsches Textarchiv, established a first set of terms and names that needed rigorous manual correction (50% error). Lists from other contemporary sources were also carefully integrated. Persons and places were identified with the help of tools semi-automatically by using CERL and Getty thesauri. At the same time, a keyword-list of objects was extracted from the collection database (approximately 820 objects). Within the special terms (TEI <term>), the objects could be identified by string matching, using a Parser written in JAVA with batch functionality, developed by the project.15 In the case of Linnaean terminology for animals, a special pattern matching was developed in case the two terms did not occur together in the text (headings and subheadings). For ambiguous terms, manual correction was required. The overall result was satisfactory, although it is, due to the established lists, limited to the German editions of the ‘Handbuch der Naturgeschichte'. Precision and recall are above 90%, and the identification of approximately 10,000 terms per text and approximately 1,000 persons/1,200 places/1,300 references to the collection database per text has been possible (Wettlaufer and Thotempudi, 2013). The following figure shows the absolute numbers of automatically tagged entities in the twelve editions of Blumenbach’s ‘Handbuch der Naturgeschichte', published between 1779 and 1830 (Fig. 1).

img.alt: Absolute numbers of tagged strings in the different editions of Blumenbachs' natural history manual from 1779 to 1830

div.p: Absolute numbers of tagged strings in the different editions of Blumenbachs' natural history manual from 1779 to 1830

img.alt: Absolute numbers of tagged strings in the different editions of Blumenbachs' natural history manual from 1779 to 1830

div.p: Absolute numbers of tagged strings in the different editions of Blumenbachs' natural history manual from 1779 to 1830

It turned out that the results for the later editions were almost as good as the results for the optimized list. The identification of objects within the terms have been encoded by reference strings (TEI <rs>), as shown in the following example:
<term xml:lang=“la” sortKey=“Hystrix_Cristata”><rs type=“Zoologie” ref=“3”>Cristata</rs></term>

In the reference string, one or more IDs could be provided to establish a link to all relevant objects in the collection. Persons are tagged as <persName> in the texts and are identified by a CERL number. Place Names have been identified by a <placeName> tag and the appropriate Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN) number. Dates have been identified in the texts by regular expressions and marked up with the <date> element.
After the NER, a manual correction took place that took care of obvious errors due to ambiguous word sense. Up to now, three texts have been corrected.
div.h3: 2.2 Modelling and mapping data to ECRM
div.p: After the annotation of the TEI texts, the modelling of the data in ECRM and the creation of an application ontology was central to the project. The ‘semblu' ontology, written in OWL 1.0, was created using Protégé 3.5.16 The basic concept classes are also reflected in the pathbuilder of WissKI, the central connection of the framework to the application ontology. Through the ontological mapping process, WissKI enables the creation of new methods for scientific workflow and content management. It is also the foundation of a semantic text annotation mechanism that allows the ‘ingest' of structured information into the system while entering full text in predefined forms. The text is analysed to connect the entities (names, places, dates, etc.) to the systems knowledge base (i.e. Getty TGN, CERL).

WissKI currently exists as several extension modules written for the Drupal 6 content management platform. The main RDF storage functionality of the WissKI core is built on ARC2, an RDF system written in PHP. ARC2 also includes a SPARQL Endpoint class that allows for the remote retrieval and manipulation of the ingested RDF data by means of queries. The SPARQL Endpoint is perceived as the main export mechanism for the production of linked open data (Meroño-Peñuela and Hoekstra, 2014).

An interface to the triple store is provided through forms. The core forms field constructor of the WissKI system is provided with the ‘pathbuilder' module. This tool allows the administrator to construct semantic definitions for the content creation of the system based on the loaded ontologies. ECRM is the top reference ontology, but application ontologies can be created to suit all possible use cases that can be covered (Fig. 2).

img.alt: WissKI conceptual model. The Application Ontologies layer allows for specific adaptation of the ECRM for a given project

div.p: WissKI conceptual model. The Application Ontologies layer allows for specific adaptation of the ECRM for a given project

img.alt: WissKI conceptual model. The Application Ontologies layer allows for specific adaptation of the ECRM for a given project

div.p: WissKI conceptual model. The Application Ontologies layer allows for specific adaptation of the ECRM for a given project

As already said above, the Erlangen CRM/OWL is an OWL-DL 1.0 implementation of the CIDOC CRM. Therefore, it is an interpretation of the CIDOC CRM in a logical framework, attempting to be as close as possible to the text of the specification.17 For the Semantic Blumenbach project, it was important to model the text and the objects with equal rights. As point of departure for Objects, the ECRM class E18_ Physical_Thing was chosen, because moveable objects from the natural history domain cannot be described in a creation process like man-made objects. On the other hand, E33_Linguistic_Object is the best candidate to model the text. In a simplified model, the text–object relationship can therefore be modelled as shown in Fig. 3.

img.alt: Text–object relationship (simplified model)

div.p: Text–object relationship (simplified model)

img.alt: Text–object relationship (simplified model)

div.p: Text–object relationship (simplified model)

The actual modelling has to take into account the complexity of the linguistic object. In this case, we have to deal with a book that can be divided into chapters. Each chapter consists of words, and some of these words are actual terms in the sense of Semantic Blumenbach, which have reference strings to objects of the Blumenbach collections. The unique identifier of each object constitutes the link between the term and the object. Other than persons and places, it is rather difficult to find suitable authorities for such heterogeneous objects as bones and artefacts from the animal kingdom, including man and stones, minerals, and chemical substances that occur in nature.18 The actual relation in the triples is expressed with SKOS:exactMatch, therefore describing the exact match of strings rather than claiming a semantic match of this quality. As already explained, the modelling of the data reflects the application ontology and the paths in the so-called ‘pathbuilder’ in WissKI. The following figure gives an overview of the model via the paths (Fig. 4).

img.alt: WissKI Pathbuilder reflecting the data model through paths

div.p: WissKI Pathbuilder reflecting the data model through paths

img.alt: WissKI Pathbuilder reflecting the data model through paths

div.p: WissKI Pathbuilder reflecting the data model through paths

One of the major tasks of the project was to establish a workflow for the ingest of data into the WissKI system and the parallel serialization of statements (as triples) that are stored in the triple store. We decided to ingest the texts first and connect the objects in a following step to the objects. The triplification of the four aforesaid entities (object, person, place, date) is accomplished with an XSL-stylesheet.19 At the core of the ingest process is a new WissKI module (TEI text), which was developed by Martin Scholz during the project.20 The module splits longer texts into smaller portions using the <div> structure for effective triplification and extraction of the knowledge and depends on the Drupal Book module. For the structured import of book length text, an import form was created and associated with the book module. This WissKI book import allows settings to provide the chapters and the whole book with meaningful title.21 The book module allows browsing the text by chapter and the text-display has been modified to display the semantic markup of the text.

In the next step, the collection database has been imported to WissKI. This was done via the database import module.22 The collection database was provided by Blumenbach-online together with approximately 4,000 photos of objects, stored as jpeg that are connected to the datasets via relational tables. Each object came with a possible set of 120 fields, from which ten have been chosen for ingest to the WissKI system: unique ID (KerndatenID), inventory number, object description, original label, object domain, place where the object was found, date when the object was found, page reference to text, donator, CERL of donator, reference to pictures.

For the process of disambiguation, there is an option in the pathbuilder to tell the system that while ingestion takes place, it shall check for already-existing identifiers and connect the triples to the already existing data. Although the feature was originally designed to disambiguate authority data, it also works to connect E18_Physical_Things with E33_Linguistic_Objects.

The ingest of the objects took place in several steps, starting with the actual data. After the ingest of the object data, the links to the pictures were ingested accordingly. The result can be viewed through the browse function or searched with forms that are created on the fly with the information in the pathbuilder.

The established relationship between text and objects can be best visualized by looking at the resulting Graph of the triples. WissKI provides a module to render the graph visible. In the example case of the rattle of a crested porcupine, we have established connections to the 4th and 7th chapter and the index of the ‘Handbuch der Naturgeschichte'. On the left figure, the graph of chapter 4 is centred around the above-mentioned object with the identifier #3, labelled ‘Rasselbecher vom rezenten Kap-Stachelschwein'. Through the instance of a unique word-identifier (wordidp10651696), the object is connected to the 4th chapter (heading: ‘Vierter Abschnitt‘) and through E41_Appellation with the other properties of the object. The graph on the right side is also centred around the object, but not from the perspective of a chapter but as an object of the collection. Here, the ingested information from the MySQL database is visible as well as the relation of the object other chapters in the book (Fig. 5).

img.alt: Graph view of the relationship between an object and a text (-chapter)

div.p: Graph view of the relationship between an object and a text (-chapter)

img.alt: Graph view of the relationship between an object and a text (-chapter)

div.p: Graph view of the relationship between an object and a text (-chapter)

The detailed data are presented in Drupal boxes by WissKI. The book chapters are displayed in formatted plain text (line breaks and paragraphs). The ingested data from the collection database are also displayed in a structured way (see Fig. 4). The vocabulary module of WissKI is used to handle Authorities and other vocabulary. A vocabulary in this sense consists of a set of entries, each having a fixed number of fields (properties/values). These fields serve to uniformly access certain information common to all or some vocabularies, while each vocabulary may choose whether to fill a field or not. Fields are used to capture properties like the preferred label (the only one that is mandatory), alternate labels, spatial coordinates, or references to broader/narrower/parental entries. In order to link local data with a vocabulary entry, the WissKI system needs to know how to handle the entry's information. Thus, the entry has to be mapped to a local Pathbuilder group and its fields to ontology paths. This mapping mechanism is the core functionality of the Vocabulary Control module.

The WissKI access point module provides a SPARQL Endpoint to interface with diverse data pools. It is used by the Vocabulary Control module as a source for the vocabulary's data. For example, an access point pointing to a remote WissKI installation containing data on persons, places, and museum objects may serve as source for three vocabularies, each containing entries on either of the categories.23 In Semantic Blumenbach, we have linked the CERL and Getty TGN with the LOD of these Vocabularies (Fig. 6).24

img.alt: Display of Collection Data with related picture in an info block. On the top the identifier (3) and the object label (Rasselbecher = quill) together with an image of the object are visible

div.p: Display of Collection Data with related picture in an info block. On the top the identifier (3) and the object label (Rasselbecher = quill) together with an image of the object are visible

img.alt: Display of Collection Data with related picture in an info block. On the top the identifier (3) and the object label (Rasselbecher = quill) together with an image of the object are visible

div.p: Display of Collection Data with related picture in an info block. On the top the identifier (3) and the object label (Rasselbecher = quill) together with an image of the object are visible

Apart from the fields defined in the Vocabulary Control settings, special fields can be selected like maps or images. The default to link local URIs to external ones is skos:closeMatch. Queries for Access Points may be defined with static mappings. There are predefined queries for SKOS properties and some of the WGS84 vocabulary.25

Using RDF for the modelling of text–object relationships has several advantages over the approaches discussed so far (cf. Introduction), but also some downsides. On the pro-side, we have the well-established and standardized data format that is not only used in the restricted world of textual scholarship and cultural heritage projects, but more generally in a wide variety of use cases. Given this general advantage, using a semantic VRE like WissKI for the given task turned out to be a good choice despite some other possible alternatives. Initially, it was planned to explore also the Europeana Data Model for its abilities to establish the text–object relationship, but it soon turned out that in its actual version it is not suited to model the semantics of the inner structure of Cultural Heritage Objects.26

This is also the major concern with the results we obtained so far. Given the absence of location identifiers in the TEI schema that was adopted from the Blumenbach-online project, no exact back reference on the word or character level is possible in the actual implementation. With the usage of XML-IDs for document structure nodes, it would be possible to address specific sentences and words within the texts. So far, during the extraction of the triples, the entities are labelled with internal unique identifiers, but theses identifiers are not represented in the TEI, only in the triple store. Furthermore, the lack of established Linked Data Vocabularies for the natural history domain makes it still difficult to link the data efficiently outside the project itself.27

During the project, it became clear that the ontological quality of text–object relationship is of utmost importance for a nuanced modelling. The SKOS properties of SKOS:Related, SKOS:narrowMatch, and SKOS:broaderMatch are able to represent the different degrees of certainty that range from ‘this object has been cited in a publication' to ‘this object belongs to the same abstract class of objects as present in the database'. The technical problem exists specifically in how to model associated rather than hierarchical relationships. A SKOS vocabulary is therefore appropriate for modelling concepts where transitivity cannot be reasoned. 28

Looking at the broader question of the integration of TEI and CIDOC CRM, we can say that through the usage of RDF as a data format and ECRM as top ontology, the missing markup for object description in the TEI can be balanced. Whether this is perceived as workaround or a valid solution depends on the viewpoint one has towards the technological background and Linked Data as a whole. If one is willing to leave the established paths and frameworks of TEI online publishing, RDF and OWL allow for expressive modelling and easy provision of the data for consumption and reuse.

To conclude, we can maintain that with the additional modules developed for Semantic Blumenbach, WissKI provides a powerful and attractive environment for connecting both texts and objects in RDF within the CRM model. The ingest of already-annotated TEI-P5 texts with several hundred pages into WissKI is now possible. Through the SPARQL Endpoint and the support of LIDO as exchange format, the data can be provided for aggregation. Nevertheless, there are a few downsides. For modelling data in CIDOC CRM, we observed a steep learning curve, and the user documentation of WissKI is still incomplete.29 But these are only minor obstacles on the way to a shared vision of a historical Semantic Web as proposed recently again by Frank van Harmelen and colleagues (Meroño-Peñuela et al. 2014).
We like to thank Fabian Cremer, SUB Göttingen, for his contribution and initial suggestion for the usage of WissKI for this project.
This work was supported by the ‘Volkswagen Stiftung' as part of the Lower Saxony Digital Humanities Research Collaboration (DHFV) and the Academy of Science, Göttingen.
1 See also http://www.tei-c.org/SIG/Ontologies/guidelines/guidelinesTeiMappableCrm.xml.

2 Cf. the most common software product for cultural heritage collections and Text Editing. MuseumPlus (http://www.zetcom.com); PastPerfect Museum Software (http://www.museumsoftware.com/), database GOS (since 1981).
3 http://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/.

4 WissKI is originally a joint venture featuring three partners from different institutions and scientific domains: The Artificial Intelligence Chair from the Department of Computer Science at the Friedrich-Alexander-University of Erlangen-Nuremberg (AI), Department of Museum Informatics at the Germanisches Nationalmuseum (GNM) in Nuremberg, and the Biodiversity Informatics Group at the Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig (ZFMK) in Bonn. Goerz and Scholz, 2010; Scholz and Goerz, 2012. For more information, refer to http://www.wiss-ki.eu and https://github.com/WissKI/.
5 http://erlangen-crm.org/.
6 http://www.lido-schema.org.
7 http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/.
8 There is a formal ontology to represent the semantics of bibliographic information in CIDOC-CRM called FRBRoo. See http://www.cidoc-crm.org/frbr_inro.html.
9 http://dhfv-ent2.gcdh.de/blumenbach/ontology/ontology.owl.
10 SKOS http://www.w3.org/2009/08/skos-reference/skos.html and http://www.w3.org/2006/07/SWD/SKOS/skos-and-owl/master.html#Hybrids.

11 We like to thank the colleagues of Blumenbach-online, in particular Heiko Weber, Claudia Kroke, Alexander Gehler, and Wolfgang Böker, for their support and especially for the possibility to use the material collected by them.
12 This allows the usage of results from Semantic Blumenbach in Johann Friedrich Blumenbach online.
13 TEI Consortium. TEI P5: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange. 2.5.0 TEI Consortium, 2013.

14 Jurish, B. and Thomas, Chr. (2013). Named Entity Recognition (NER) im Deutschen Textarchiv. Computerlinguistisch gestützte Identifikation von Personen- und Ortsnamen in den Korpora des DTA <www.deutschestextarchiv.de/files/DTAE-NER_vortrag-2013-03-06.pdf>.
15 http://dhfv-ent2.gcdh.de/Tagging/.
16 http://protege.stanford.edu/.
17 http://erlangen-crm.org/.

18 One possible reference point for the animals in Blumenbach texts could be AnimalBase, a project of the University of Göttingen that started in 2003 and aims at providing access to digitized zoological works before 1800 and a manually verified list of names of zoological genera and species. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AnimalBase. Another would be the INDEX ANIMALIUM by Charles Davies Sherborn: http://www.sil.si.edu/digitalcollections/indexanimalium/. For minerals mindat.org provides stable URIs and references to classification systems (Nickel-Strunz, Dana, Hey).
19 http://dhfv-ent2.gcdh.de/blumenbach/wisski/sites/all/modules/wisski_texttei/triplify.xsl.
20 https://github.com/mnscholz/wisski_texttei.
21 https://github.com/WissKI/wisski_book_import.
22 https://github.com/WissKI/wisski_sql_import/blob/master/wisski_sql_import.module.
23 http://wiss-ki.eu/node/165.
24 http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/lod/; http://www.cerl.org/resources/cerl_thesaurus/linkeddata.
25 WGS84 = World Geodetic System 1984. https://github.com/WissKI/wisski_vocab_ctrl.
26 EDM Definition - http://pro.europeana.eu/documents/900548/0d0f6ec3-1905-4c4f-96c8-1d817c03123c.
27 See http://www.heritagedata.org/ for a limited example of vocabularies for English archaeology. http://data.bgs.ac.uk/ provides linked data for geology.
28 http://www.w3.org/TR/skos-primer/#secrel.

29 There is the idea of starting a repository with use cases that could help new users to model their data accordingly to the already-existing installations of WissKI. Currently, the modules are ported to Drupal 7. For more information, refer to the Website of the project www.wiss-ki.eu.
